answers.feedback_html: Using Hooke’s Law, the value of the force constant comes out to be 1.93 \times 10^4\,\text{N/m}.
The force will be the weight of the 65\,\text{kg} person sitting inside the car. Try to find weight when mass is given.
Be careful about the units. Keep all quantities in SI units, to obtain the force constant in \text{N/m}.
The force is mass times acceleration due to gravity. Also, convert the displacement of the suspension system given in centimeters to meters, so that the unit for the force constant is \text{N/m}.

stem_html: What is the force constant for the suspension system of a car that settles 3.3\,\text{cm} when a 65\,\text{kg} person gets in?

answers.content_html: The negative sign indicates that displacement decreases with increasing force.
answers.feedback_html: Review Hooke’s law. Force is directly proportional to the displacement.

answers.content_html: The negative sign indicates that the direction of the applied force is opposite to that of displacement.
answers.feedback_html: Hooke’s law gives the equation F = {-k}x. Here, F is the restoring force, not the applied force.

answers.content_html: The negative sign indicates that the direction of the restoring force is opposite to that of displacement.
answers.feedback_html: The negative sign indicates that F and x must have opposite signs.

answers.content_html: The negative sign indicates that the force constant must be negative.
answers.feedback_html: Force constant is always a positive quantity.

stem_html: Why is there a negative sign in the equation for Hooke’s law?

answers.feedback_html: For larger angles, the motion is no longer governed by Hooke’s law.
45^\circ\! is one fourth of 180^\circ\!. With this amplitude, the motion is not simple harmonic.
Think about how large this amplitude is; the motion of a simple pendulum is no longer a simple harmonic.
This amplitude is very large and the resulting motion won’t be simple harmonic in nature.

stem_html: Up to approximately what angle is simple harmonic motion a good model for a pendulum?

answers.content_html: No, it is not a natural science because it is not used in the study of the natural world.
answers.feedback_html: Mathematics is used in the study of the natural world, but that does not explain whether it is a natural science.

answers.content_html: No, it is not a natural science. Mathematics focuses on understanding mathematical relations and calculations, which is useful in natural sciences but which is distinct.
answers.feedback_html: Mathematics is not a natural science as it does not use chemical and physical measurements like other fields in natural sciences.

answers.content_html: Yes, it is a natural science. Mathematics deals with verifying the experimental data.
answers.feedback_html: Mathematics does not use the chemical and physical measurements, therefore it is not natural science.

answers.content_html: Yes, it is a natural science. It uses chemical and physical measurements.
answers.feedback_html: Mathematics does not use chemical and physical measurements.

stem_html: Is mathematics a natural science? Explain your reasoning.
